messageBody:
>I've found that I never need to construct test suites. My package

Ah, an extreme viewpoint. I love those.

I've found some value in using TestSuite to structure and order tests,
but we have consider replacing that with some sort of finder. I'd love
to hear positive experiences.

When we created the TestSuite classes initially, we ordered the tests
so that the more "primitive" classes are tested first. That way, if a
developer manages to break something badly, the first failure tends to
be interesting. The ordering was useful for doing some large
refactorings; fixing those first failures often fixed the later,
larger-grained tests.

We've also got some platform-specific automated tests we are starting
to write and it's useful to *not* run those on platforms other than the
expected one. For example, we have some code that does testing specific
to personal Java and we'll likely be adding some that is specific to
MIDP. So, if we use an automated test finder, it needs to have a way to
categorize tests and selectively include/exclude certain categories.

An alternative would be to add more CVS modules and use them to
categorize tests, but I think that complicates the development/build
environment more than it pays in testability benefit.

Regards,

Rob
